title: Temporal Disaggregation of IBM's GHG Emissions
text: vignette, demonstrate use DisaggregateTS package perform temporal disaggregation IBM‚Äôs greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions data. goal estimate quarterly GHG emissions based annual data, leveraging high-frequency economic indicators.

title: Temporal Disaggregation of IBM's GHG Emissions
text: focusing emissions per unit economic output, carbon intensity accounts fact larger organizations economies may naturally produce emissions simply due scale. allows fair comparison sustainability performance across different entities, regardless size. Accurate timely carbon accounting development robust measurement frameworks essential effective emission reduction strategies pursuit sustainable development goals. carbon accounting frameworks offer valuable insights emissions quantification, without limitations. One limitations frequency information released, generally annual frequency, companies‚Äô economic indicators made public quarterly basis. perfect example temporal disaggregation can used bridge gap data availability prompt economic financial analyses. application, variable interest GHG emissions IBM Q3 2005 Q3 2021, annual frequency, resulting 17 data points (.e., ùêò‚àà‚Ñù17\mathbf{Y} \\mathbb{R}^{17}). high-frequency data, used balance sheet, income statement, cash flow statement quarterly data Q3 2005 Q3 2021, resulting 68 data points 112 variables (filtering). remove variables pairwise correlation higher 0.99, resulting filtered dataset 112 variables (ùêó‚àà‚Ñù68√ó112\mathbf{X} \\mathbb{R}^{68 \times 112}). example, employ adaptive LASSO method (method = "adaptive-spTD") select best variables can used recover high-frequency observations, apply aggMat = "first" aggregation method.

title: Temporal Disaggregation of IBM's GHG Emissions
text: start loading required packages data.
code: library(DisaggregateTS) # Load the combined data from the package data(Data)  # Extract Data_Y and Data_X from the combined data Data_Y <- Data$Data_Y Data_X <- Data$Data_X  # Select IBM GHG data and dates for Q3 2005 - Q3 2021 Dates <- Data_Y$Dates[c(7:23)] Y <- Data_Y$IBM[c(7:23)] Y <- as.matrix(as.numeric(Y))  # HF data available from 12-2004 (observation 21) up to 09-2021 (observation 88) Dates_Q <- Data_X$Dates[c(21:88)] X <- Data_X[c(21:88),] X <- sapply(X, as.numeric) #> Warning in lapply(X = X, FUN = FUN, ...): NAs introduced by coercion  # Remove columns containing NAs X <- X[ , colSums(is.na(X))==0]    # Remove highly correlated variables (pairwise correlation >= 0.99) tmp <- cor(X) tmp[upper.tri(tmp)] <- 0 diag(tmp) <- 0  X2 <- X[, !apply(tmp, 2, function(x) any(abs(x) >= 0.99, na.rm = TRUE))]

title: Temporal Disaggregation of IBM's GHG Emissions
code: C_sparse <- disaggregate(   as.matrix(Y),   as.matrix(X2),   aggMat   = "sum",   aggRatio = 4,   method   = "adaptive-spTD")  # Temporally disaggregated time series Y_HF <- C_sparse$y_Est

title: Temporal Disaggregation of IBM's GHG Emissions
code: par(mar = c(5, 6, 4, 5) + 0.1)  # Adjust margins for better spacing  # Plot the temporal disaggregated data plot(Dates_Q, Y_HF, type = "b", pch = 19, ylab = "GHG emissions", xlab = "Time",      lwd = 2, cex.lab = 1.4, cex.axis = 1.2, main = "Temporal Disaggregation of GHG Emissions")  # Add a legend with adjusted font size and position legend("bottomleft", inset = 0.05,         legend = "Temporal disaggregated observations",        col = "black", lty = 1, lwd = 2, pch = 19,         cex = 1.2, pt.cex = 1.2)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kaveh Salehzadeh Nobari. Author, maintainer. Luke Mosley. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Salehzadeh Nobari K, Mosley L (2025). DisaggregateTS: High-Dimensional Temporal Disaggregation. R package version 3.0.1, https://github.com/kavehsn/DisaggregateTS.
code: @Manual{,   title = {DisaggregateTS: High-Dimensional Temporal Disaggregation},   author = {Kaveh {Salehzadeh Nobari} and Luke Mosley},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 3.0.1},   url = {https://github.com/kavehsn/DisaggregateTS}, }

title: High-Dimensional Temporal Disaggregation
text: goal DisaggregateTS provide tools temporal disaggregation, including: (1) high-dimensional low-dimensional series generation simulation studies; (2) toolkit temporal disaggregation benchmarking using low-dimensional indicator series proposed Dagum Cholette; (3) novel techniques Mosley, Gibberd, Eckley (2022) disaggregating low-frequency series presence high-dimensional indicator matrices.

title: High-Dimensional Temporal Disaggregation
text: install update CRAN can install development version DisaggregateTS GitHub :
code: # install.packages("DisaggregateTS") install.packages("DisaggregateTS") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("kavehsn/DisaggregateTS")

title: High-Dimensional Temporal Disaggregation
text: TempDisaggDGP() generates high-frequency response vector y, following relationship y=XŒ≤+œµy = X\beta+\epsilon, XX matrix indicator series Œ≤\beta potentially sparse coefficient vector. low-frequency vector YY generated aggregating yy according specified aggregation method. hand, disaggregate() function contains traditional standard-dimensional temporal disaggregation methods proposed Denton (1971), Dagum Cholette (2006), Chow Lin (1971), Fern√°ndez (1981) Litterman (1983), high-dimensional methods Mosley et al.¬†(2022). Please report bugs Kaveh Nobari.
code: library(DisaggregateTS) ## basic example code data <- TempDisaggDGP(n_l=25, n=100, p=10, rho=0.5)  X <- data$X_Gen Y <- data$Y_Gen  fit_chowlin <- disaggregate(Y=Y,X=X,method='Chow-Lin')  y_hat = fit_chowlin$y_Est

what: Function to generate an AR(1) variance-covariance matrix with parameter rho s.t. \(\lvert \rho\rvert < 1\). ‚Äî ARcov
title: Function to generate an AR(1) variance-covariance matrix with parameter rho s.t. \(\lvert \rho\rvert < 1\). ‚Äî ARcov
text: Function generate AR(1) variance-covariance matrix parameter rho s.t. \(\lvert \rho\rvert  < 1\).

title: Function to generate an AR(1) variance-covariance matrix with parameter rho s.t. \(\lvert \rho\rvert < 1\). ‚Äî ARcov
code: ARcov(rho, n)

title: Function to generate an AR(1) variance-covariance matrix with parameter rho s.t. \(\lvert \rho\rvert < 1\). ‚Äî ARcov
text: rho Numeric value representing autocorrelation parameter. Must satisfy |rho| < 1. n Integer representing size matrix (n x n).

title: Function to generate an AR(1) variance-covariance matrix with parameter rho s.t. \(\lvert \rho\rvert < 1\). ‚Äî ARcov
text: variance-covariance matrix size n x n based AR(1) process.

what: Function to generate an ARIMA(1,1,0) variance-covariance matrix for the Litterman method with parameter \(\rho\) such that \(\lvert \rho \rvert < 1\). ‚Äî ARcov_lit
title: Function to generate an ARIMA(1,1,0) variance-covariance matrix for the Litterman method with parameter \(\rho\) such that \(\lvert \rho \rvert < 1\). ‚Äî ARcov_lit
text: Function generate ARIMA(1,1,0) variance-covariance matrix Litterman method parameter \(\rho\) \(\lvert \rho \rvert < 1\).

title: Function to generate an ARIMA(1,1,0) variance-covariance matrix for the Litterman method with parameter \(\rho\) such that \(\lvert \rho \rvert < 1\). ‚Äî ARcov_lit
code: ARcov_lit(rho, n)

title: Function to generate an ARIMA(1,1,0) variance-covariance matrix for the Litterman method with parameter \(\rho\) such that \(\lvert \rho \rvert < 1\). ‚Äî ARcov_lit
text: rho Numeric value representing autocorrelation parameter. Must satisfy \(\lvert \rho \rvert < 1\). n Integer representing size matrix \((n x n)\).

title: Function to generate an ARIMA(1,1,0) variance-covariance matrix for the Litterman method with parameter \(\rho\) such that \(\lvert \rho \rvert < 1\). ‚Äî ARcov_lit
text: variance-covariance matrix size \((n x n)\) ARIMA(1,1,0) process, used Litterman method.

what: Function to perform Chow-Lin temporal disaggregation from chow1971best;textualDisaggregateTS and its special case counterpart, Litterman litterman1983random;textualDisaggregateTS. ‚Äî chowlin
title: Function to perform Chow-Lin temporal disaggregation from chow1971best;textualDisaggregateTS and its special case counterpart, Litterman litterman1983random;textualDisaggregateTS. ‚Äî chowlin
text: Used disaggregate find estimates given optimal \(rho\) parameter.

title: Function to perform Chow-Lin temporal disaggregation from chow1971best;textualDisaggregateTS and its special case counterpart, Litterman litterman1983random;textualDisaggregateTS. ‚Äî chowlin
code: chowlin(Y, X, rho, aggMat = "sum", aggRatio = 4, litterman = FALSE)

title: Function to perform Chow-Lin temporal disaggregation from chow1971best;textualDisaggregateTS and its special case counterpart, Litterman litterman1983random;textualDisaggregateTS. ‚Äî chowlin
text: Y low-frequency response series (\(n_l \times 1\) matrix). X high-frequency indicator series (\(n \times p\) matrix). rho AR(1) residual parameter. Must strictly \(-1\) \(1\). aggMat Aggregation matrix method: 'first', 'sum', 'average', 'last'. Default 'sum'. aggRatio Aggregation ratio, e.g. 4 annual--quarterly, 3 quarterly--monthly. Default 4. litterman Boolean. TRUE, use Litterman variance-covariance method, otherwise use Chow-Lin. Default FALSE.

title: Function to perform Chow-Lin temporal disaggregation from chow1971best;textualDisaggregateTS and its special case counterpart, Litterman litterman1983random;textualDisaggregateTS. ‚Äî chowlin
text: list containing following elements: y: Estimated high-frequency response series (\(n \times 1\) matrix). betaHat: Estimated coefficient vector (\(p \times 1\) matrix). u_l: Estimated aggregate residual series (\(n_l \times 1\) matrix).

what: Likelihood function for Chow-Lin or Litterman temporal disaggregation. ‚Äî chowlin_likelihood
title: Likelihood function for Chow-Lin or Litterman temporal disaggregation. ‚Äî chowlin_likelihood
text: function computes likelihood function used temporal disaggregation find optimal \(\rho\) parameter. used conjunction disaggregate estimate autocorrelation coefficient \(\rho\).

title: Likelihood function for Chow-Lin or Litterman temporal disaggregation. ‚Äî chowlin_likelihood
code: chowlin_likelihood(Y, X, vcov)

title: Likelihood function for Chow-Lin or Litterman temporal disaggregation. ‚Äî chowlin_likelihood
text: Y low-frequency response series (\(n_l \times 1\) matrix). X aggregated high-frequency indicator series (\(n_l \times p\) matrix). vcov Aggregated variance-covariance matrix Chow-Lin Litterman residuals.

title: Likelihood function for Chow-Lin or Litterman temporal disaggregation. ‚Äî chowlin_likelihood
code: The log-likelihood value for the given parameters.

what: GHG Emissions and Financial Data for IBM ‚Äî Data
title: GHG Emissions and Financial Data for IBM ‚Äî Data
text: dataset contains time series data greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions financial variables IBM covering period Q3 2005 Q3 2021. designed use demonstrating temporal disaggregation adaptive LASSO methods estimating high-frequency GHG emissions low-frequency data.

title: GHG Emissions and Financial Data for IBM ‚Äî Data
code: Data

title: GHG Emissions and Financial Data for IBM ‚Äî Data
text: data frame 68 rows (representing quarters) 113 variables: time Numeric vector representing time index, spanning Q3 2005 Q3 2021 GHG Numeric vector annual greenhouse gas emissions IBM, recorded annually repeated quarterly financial_variables matrix data frame 112 financial variables, extracted quarterly balance sheets, income statements, cash flow statements company

title: GHG Emissions and Financial Data for IBM ‚Äî Data
text: Original data collected financial statements GHG reports IBM.

title: Temporal Disaggregation Methods ‚Äî disaggregate
text: function contains traditional standard-dimensional temporal disaggregation methods proposed denton1971adjustment;textualDisaggregateTS, dagum2006benchmarking;textualDisaggregateTS, chow1971best;textualDisaggregateTS, fernandez1981methodological;textualDisaggregateTS litterman1983random;textualDisaggregateTS, high-dimensional methods 10.1111/rssa.12952;textualDisaggregateTS.

title: Temporal Disaggregation Methods ‚Äî disaggregate
code: disaggregate(   Y,   X = matrix(data = rep(1, times = (nrow(Y) * aggRatio)), nrow = (nrow(Y) * aggRatio)),   aggMat = "sum",   aggRatio = 4,   method = "Chow-Lin",   Denton = "additive-first-diff" )

title: Temporal Disaggregation Methods ‚Äî disaggregate
text: Y low-frequency response series (\(n_l \times 1\) matrix). X high-frequency indicator series (\(n \times p\) matrix). aggMat Aggregation matrix according 'first', 'sum', 'average', 'last' (default 'sum'). aggRatio Aggregation ratio e.g. 4 annual--quarterly, 3 quarterly--monthly (default 4). method Disaggregation method using 'Denton', 'Denton-Cholette', 'Chow-Lin', 'Fernandez', 'Litterman', 'spTD' 'adaptive-spTD' (default 'Chow-Lin'). Denton Type differencing Denton method: 'simple-diff', 'additive-first-diff', 'additive-second-diff', 'proportional-first-diff' 'proportional-second-diff' (default 'additive-first-diff'). instance, 'simple-diff' differencing refers differences original revised values, whereas 'additive-first-diff' differencing refers differences first differenced original revised values.

title: Temporal Disaggregation Methods ‚Äî disaggregate
text: y_Est:	  Estimated high-frequency response series (output \(n \times 1\) matrix). beta_Est:	Estimated coefficient vector (output \(p \times 1\) matrix). rho_Est:	Estimated residual AR(1) autocorrelation parameter. ul_Est:	  Estimated aggregate residual series (output \(n_l \times 1\) matrix).

title: Temporal Disaggregation Methods ‚Äî disaggregate
text: Takes \(n_l \times 1\) low-frequency series disaggregated \(Y\) \(n \times p\) high-frequency matrix p indicator series \(X\). \(n > n_l \times aggRatio\) \(aggRatio\) aggregation ratio (e.g. \(aggRatio = 4\) annual--quarterly disagg, \(aggRatio = 3\) quarterly--monthly disagg) extrapolation done extrapolate \(n\).

title: Temporal Disaggregation Methods ‚Äî disaggregate
code: data <- TempDisaggDGP(n_l=25,n=100,p=10,rho=0.5) X <- data$X_Gen Y <- data$Y_Gen fit_chowlin <- disaggregate(Y=Y,X=X,method='Chow-Lin') y_hat = fit_chowlin$y_Est

title: High-dimensional BIC score ‚Äî hdBIC
text: function calculates BIC score performs better ordinary BIC high-dimensional scenarios. uses variance estimator given yu2019estimating;textualDisaggregateTS.

title: High-dimensional BIC score ‚Äî hdBIC
code: hdBIC(X, Y, covariance, beta)

title: High-dimensional BIC score ‚Äî hdBIC
text: X Aggregated indicator series matrix GLS rotated (\(n_l \times p\) matrix). Y Low-frequency response vector GLS rotated (\(n_l \times 1\) vector). covariance Aggregated AR covariance matrix (\(n_l \times n_l\) matrix). beta Estimate regression coefficients (\(p \times 1\) vector).

title: High-dimensional BIC score ‚Äî hdBIC
code: The BIC score for model comparison.

what: Index of support for LARS algorithm in high-dimensional settings ‚Äî k.index
title: Index of support for LARS algorithm in high-dimensional settings ‚Äî k.index
text: function returns index support beta coefficients exceeds \(n_l/2\), preventing BIC becoming erratic high-dimensional scenarios.

title: Index of support for LARS algorithm in high-dimensional settings ‚Äî k.index
code: k.index(coef_matrix, n_l)

title: Index of support for LARS algorithm in high-dimensional settings ‚Äî k.index
text: coef_matrix matrix beta coefficients, rows represent different models. n_l length low-frequency response series.

title: Index of support for LARS algorithm in high-dimensional settings ‚Äî k.index
code: The index where the support of beta exceeds \eqn{n_l/2}, or the number of rows of the matrix if no such index is found.

what: Refit LASSO estimate into GLS ‚Äî refit
title: Refit LASSO estimate into GLS ‚Äî refit
text: function reduces bias LASSO estimates re-fitting active set coefficients back GLS (Generalized Least Squares).

title: Refit LASSO estimate into GLS ‚Äî refit
code: refit(X, Y, beta)

title: Refit LASSO estimate into GLS ‚Äî refit
text: X Aggregated indicator series matrix GLS rotated (\(n_l \times p\) matrix). Y Low-frequency response vector GLS rotated (\(n_l \times 1\) vector). beta Estimated beta coefficients LARS algorithm (\(p \times 1\) vector).

title: Refit LASSO estimate into GLS ‚Äî refit
code: A debiased estimate of the beta coefficients (a \eqn{p \times 1} vector).

title: Simulation Diagnostics ‚Äî simulDiagnosis
text: function provides diagnostics evaluating accuracy simulated data. Specifically, computes Mean Squared Error (MSE) true estimated response vectors, optionally, sign recovery percentage coefficient vector.

title: Simulation Diagnostics ‚Äî simulDiagnosis
code: simulDiagnosis(data_Hat, data_True, sgn = FALSE)

title: Simulation Diagnostics ‚Äî simulDiagnosis
text: data_Hat List containing estimated high-frequency data, components y_Est (estimated response vector) beta_Est (estimated coefficient vector). data_True List containing true high-frequency data, components y_Gen (true response vector) Beta_Gen (true coefficient vector). sgn Logical value indicating whether compute sign recovery percentage. Default FALSE.

title: Simulation Diagnostics ‚Äî simulDiagnosis
text: sgn FALSE, function returns Mean Squared Error (MSE) true estimated response vectors. sgn TRUE, function returns list containing MSE sign recovery percentage.

title: Simulation Diagnostics ‚Äî simulDiagnosis
text: function takes generated high-frequency data (data_True) estimated high-frequency data (data_Hat), returns Mean Squared Error (MSE) true estimated values response vector. sgn parameter set TRUE, function additionally computes percentage correctly recovered signs coefficient vector.

title: Simulation Diagnostics ‚Äî simulDiagnosis
code: true_data <- list(y_Gen = c(1, 2, 3), Beta_Gen = c(1, -1, 0)) est_data <- list(y_Est = c(1.1, 1.9, 2.8), beta_Est = c(1, 1, 0)) mse <- simulDiagnosis(est_data, true_data) results <- simulDiagnosis(est_data, true_data, sgn = TRUE)

title: Sparse Temporal Disaggregation ‚Äî sptd
text: function performs sparse temporal disaggregation described 10.1111/rssa.12952;textualDisaggregateTS. estimates high-frequency response series using LARS (Least Angle Regression) applies either LASSO adaptive LASSO penalty.

title: Sparse Temporal Disaggregation ‚Äî sptd
code: sptd(Y, X, rho, aggMat = "sum", aggRatio = 4, adaptive = FALSE)

title: Sparse Temporal Disaggregation ‚Äî sptd
text: Y low-frequency response series (\(n_l \times 1\) matrix). X high-frequency indicator series (\(n \times p\) matrix). rho AR(\(1\)) residual parameter (must strictly \(-1\) \(1\)). aggMat Aggregation matrix method ('first', 'sum', 'average', 'last'). Default 'sum'. aggRatio Aggregation ratio (e.g., 4 annual--quarterly, 3 quarterly--monthly). Default 4. adaptive Logical. TRUE, use adaptive LASSO penalty. FALSE, use standard LASSO penalty. Default FALSE.

title: Sparse Temporal Disaggregation ‚Äî sptd
text: list containing: y: Estimated high-frequency response series (\(n \times 1\) matrix). betaHat: Estimated coefficient vector (\(p \times 1\) matrix). u_l: Estimated aggregate residual series (\(n_l \times 1\) matrix).

what: BIC Score for Sparse Temporal Disaggregation ‚Äî sptd_BIC
title: BIC Score for Sparse Temporal Disaggregation ‚Äî sptd_BIC
text: function calculates BIC score sparse temporal disaggregation, described 10.1111/rssa.12952;textualDisaggregateTS. uses LARS algorithm find optimal beta coefficients refits models compute BIC scores.

title: BIC Score for Sparse Temporal Disaggregation ‚Äî sptd_BIC
code: sptd_BIC(Y, X, vcov)

title: BIC Score for Sparse Temporal Disaggregation ‚Äî sptd_BIC
text: Y low-frequency response series (\(n_l \times 1\) matrix). X aggregated high-frequency indicator series (\(n_l \times p\) matrix). vcov Aggregated variance-covariance matrix AR(\(1\)) residuals (\(n_l \times n_l\) matrix).

title: BIC Score for Sparse Temporal Disaggregation ‚Äî sptd_BIC
code: The minimum BIC score from the refitted models.

what: High and Low-Frequency Data Generating Processes ‚Äî TempDisaggDGP
title: High and Low-Frequency Data Generating Processes ‚Äî TempDisaggDGP
text: function generates high-frequency response vector \(y\), following relationship \(y = X\beta + \epsilon\), \(X\) matrix indicator series \(\beta\) potentially sparse coefficient vector. low-frequency vector \(Y\) generated aggregating \(y\) according specified aggregation method.

title: High and Low-Frequency Data Generating Processes ‚Äî TempDisaggDGP
code: TempDisaggDGP(   n_l,   n,   aggRatio = 4,   p = 1,   beta = 1,   sparsity = 1,   method = "Chow-Lin",   aggMat = "sum",   rho = 0,   mean_X = 0,   sd_X = 1,   sd_e = 1,   simul = FALSE,   sparse_option = "random",   setSeed = 42 )

title: High and Low-Frequency Data Generating Processes ‚Äî TempDisaggDGP
text: n_l Integer. Size low-frequency series. n Integer. Size high-frequency series. aggRatio Integer. Aggregation ratio low high frequency (default 4). p Integer. Number high-frequency indicator series include. beta Numeric. Value positive negative elements coefficient vector. sparsity Numeric. Sparsity percentage coefficient vector (value 0 1). method Character. DGP residuals use ('Denton', 'Denton-Cholette', 'Chow-Lin', 'Fernandez', 'Litterman'). aggMat Character. Aggregation matrix type ('first', 'sum', 'average', 'last'). rho Numeric. Residual autocorrelation coefficient (default 0). mean_X Numeric. Mean design matrix (default 0). sd_X Numeric. Standard deviation design matrix (default 1). sd_e Numeric. Standard deviation errors (default 1). simul Logical. TRUE, design matrix coefficient vector fixed (default FALSE). sparse_option Character Integer. Option specify sparsity coefficient vector ('random' integer value). Default "random". setSeed Integer. Seed value reproducibility simul set TRUE.

title: High and Low-Frequency Data Generating Processes ‚Äî TempDisaggDGP
text: list containing following components: y_Gen: Generated high-frequency response series (\(n \times 1\) matrix). Y_Gen: Generated low-frequency response series (\(n_l \times 1\) matrix). X_Gen: Generated high-frequency indicator series (\(n \times p\) matrix). Beta_Gen: Generated coefficient vector (\(p \times 1\) matrix). e_Gen: Generated high-frequency residual series (\(n \times 1\) matrix).

title: High and Low-Frequency Data Generating Processes ‚Äî TempDisaggDGP
text: aggregation ratio (aggRatio) determines ratio low high-frequency series (e.g., aggRatio = 4 annual--quarterly). number observations \(n\) exceeds \(aggRatio \times n_l\), aggregation matrix include zero columns extrapolated values. function supports several data generating processes (DGP) residuals, including 'Denton', 'Denton-Cholette', 'Chow-Lin', 'Fernandez', 'Litterman'. methods differ generate high-frequency data residuals, optional autocorrelation specified rho.

title: High and Low-Frequency Data Generating Processes ‚Äî TempDisaggDGP
code: data <- TempDisaggDGP(n_l=25,n=100,p=10,rho=0.5) X <- data$X_Gen Y <- data$Y_Gen
